user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_boundary:
```c
static int
find_boundary (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
               const char *boundary,
               size_t blen,
               size_t *ioffptr,
               enum PP_State next_state,
               enum PP_State next_dash_state)
{
  char *buf = (char *) &pp[1];
  const char *dash;

  if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen)
  {
    if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size)
      pp->state = PP_Error;     /* out of memory */
    /* ++(*ioffptr); */
    return MHD_NO;              /* not enough data */
  }
  if ( (0 != memcmp ("--",
                     buf,
                     2)) ||
       (0 != memcmp (&buf[2],
                     boundary,
                     blen)))
  {
    if (pp->state != PP_Init)
    {
      /* garbage not allowed */
      pp->state = PP_Error;
    }
    else
    {
      /* skip over garbage (RFC 2046, 5.1.1) */
      dash = memchr (buf,
                     '-',
                     pp->buffer_pos);
      if (NULL == dash)
        (*ioffptr) += pp->buffer_pos;         /* skip entire buffer */
      else if (dash == buf)
        (*ioffptr)++;                         /* at least skip one byte */
      else
        (*ioffptr) += (size_t) (dash - buf);  /* skip to first possible boundary */
    }
    return MHD_NO;                            /* expected boundary */
  }
  /* remove boundary from buffer */
  (*ioffptr) += 2 + blen;
  /* next: start with headers */
  pp->skip_rn = RN_Dash;
  pp->state = next_state;
  pp->dash_state = next_dash_state;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function find_boundary:
const void *buffer
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(0 != memcmp (&buf[2],
                     boundary,
                     blen))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The memcmp call is reached only when pp->buffer_pos >= 2 + blen (the function returns earlier if pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen), so comparing blen bytes from &buf[2] cannot read past the pp buffer. Therefore this fragment does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (Caveat: the rule would be violated if the caller provides a boundary pointer that is not valid for blen bytes — that is a caller precondition, not a problem in this fragment.)
